summary: To fight money laundering and other crimes, the Bank Secrecy Act requires banks to verify customers’ identities and report suspicious activities. We looked at federal oversight of banks’ compliance with these requirements—particularly when banks’ customers are money transmitting businesses. Some federal bank examiners were unclear about how much due diligence they should expect from banks’ site visits and reviews of their money transmitter customers. We...
title: Bank Secrecy Act: Examiners Need More Information on How to Assess Banks' Compliance Controls for Money Transmitter Accounts
